text: Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? Well I guess they’re two independent things then. Doctor: It’s two, it’s two independent things. You are a extremely low risk gist tumor. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And and the risk is not determined by the size. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s determined by um how rapidly the cells are dividing, so there’s something that’s called a mitosis. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A mitosis means however the cell’s dividing. And you have like the very lowest mitotic rate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So your gist basically it’s it’s a really dumb one; it doesn’t really know how to metastasize. So when you’ve got a cancer, you’d rather have a dumb one than a smart one. You had a really dumb gist tumor. But you’ve kind of got a smarter prostate cancer. So the gist tumor I think is extremely unlikely… Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …to spread to a lymphnode although it is theoretically possible. But what is far more likely given the fact that you have a prostate cancer with you know high Gleason score and a PSA that is rising… Patient: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Well okay so you’re talking three different options. Doctor: Yeah basically. Patient: Which one, which one I guess was your recommendation? Doctor: What I was going to propose is that we do things in parallel. Okay? I was going to sort of leave the chemotherapy as a last possible option only because you have it available at any time. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: You know we can go to it if none of these work or even after they work and then stop working after sometime. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And who knows what we may have by then too. If you don’t need it at all at that time. The, the I was going to sugg-propose that we do the prescreening and the blood test in anticipation of doing that testing for your blood today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that way we have at least that cooking… Family Member: Check the markers and? Doctor: Right. If the markers are positive, I think you should go on the Niraparib, the PARP inhibitor - the targeted treatment…

text: Patient: Okay, okay. But it never will go in remission, it will never be gone? Doctor: Well remission’s a tough word in cancer. Patient: I know. Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Remission would imply that everything is gone and when you have scans that are never going to be right, it’s hard for me to say you’re in remission. Patient: Sure, sure. Doctor: So we use words like response. You know are you having a good response? Is it a durable response? Is it a complete response? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And those are probably words that we opt to use. Um, If you have testicle cancer we could say remission Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because then you don’t see anything. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s nothing in the blood work all your scans are clean, then you can say wow I see nothing Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, let’s go to the data. You are on therapy, really tolerating it okay? Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And I would say, no worse for the wear? Patient: Nope. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
